answers.answer: Did your ultrasound show nodules?  The possibilities (typically) with this scenario are Graves' disease (most likely) or toxic nodule(s).  If no nodules on US then likely Graves' given 42% uptake - but would confirm with TSI blood test.Given the symptoms, once the diagnosis is more clear, would usually give a modes dose of methimazole at 5-10mg / day to normalize the TSH and re-evaluate symptoms.Also test cortisol to screen for adrenal insufficiency.

question: Hi there, I'm a 28 year old white female.  During my physical this year I mentioned to my doctor the symptoms i've been having over the last time I saw her the year before.  I'm always thirsty, have a hard time falling asleep..but sleeping through the night isn't a problem.. I have developed a fine tremor in my hands, I dropped 30 lbs the year before, but now have gained it back, my body is exhausted, I have hot flashes almost every day and several times a day at that, my blood presure has been fairly low with an average of 90/60, but my heart rate at resting is between 85-100.  My physician ran some labs, ruled out diabetes, but did find my TSH was <0.03, more labs followed with a Triiodthyronine at 3.7, and Free Thyroxine at 1.4.  Thyroglobulin showed 22.1, TPO 2.7, Thyroglobulin Antibody <20.0.  I was refered to an endo with the dx of hyperthyroidism.  I had an I123 uptake and scan test done, with a result of 42% uptake.  The images are still being deciphered.  I'm wondering if my TSH seems to be the only thing that is really wrong, is there a need for treatment?  My heart rate seems to be slowing at night as I am taking Ativan to slow it down as opposed to a Beta Blocker (I insisted on not taking a beta blocker due to my already low blood pressure).  I've done research, and these numbers are not consistant with a lot of dx of thyroid issues I have looked up.  Thanks for your advice!
title: TSH <0.03
